class.title: Visual Design for New Media
class.description: This course will focus on designing client centered Web sites unifying layout, color, typography and imagery using Adobe Dreamweaver, Fireworks and Photoshop applications. Prior knowledge of producing Websites using XHTML and CSS is required. A campus section of this class is offered in the Fall Term Only. Questions? Call Lauri Collins at 972-860-4308 or e-mail LCollins@dcccd.edu.

class.title: Digital Publishing II
class.description: This course provides the student study and application in design studio practices creating and producing real-world print projects. The student serves as a designer, illustrator, computer graphics artist and/or art director in the Brookhaven College Visual Communications Design Studio. A portfolio is required for approval prior to registration. Monday/Wednesday attendance is MANDATORY, however remaining lab hours per week are arranged individually. For questions and/or approval, contact Jerry Hill e-mail jhHill@dcccd.edu.

class.title: Principles of Nutrition
class.description: In addition to learning how the body handles nutrients, students in this course will: analyze personal eating habits; develop a personal weight control plan; analyze food labels; distinguish between nutrition fact and myth; identify relationships between nutrition and disease; and integrate nutrition information into daily lives. There is an Internet component, so students must have Internet access and an e-mail account.

class.title: Problem Solv. and Dec. Making
class.description: Complete two courses one night per week. Be mentored by full-time business faculty. Class format includes small-group discussions and networking with other employed professionals. Students taking management program courses at Brookhaven for the first time must be advised by the faculty before they register. Call Mary Lou Avera at 972-860-4179, e-mail her at MaryLou@dcccd.edu or visit www.BrookhavenCollege.edu/management.

class.description: Complete two courses one night per week. Earn credit through goal-setting in your current employment. Gain visibility at work while becoming more promotable and marketable. Must be taken with BMGT 2303. First-time students must be advised by the faculty member before they register. Call Mary Lou Avera at 972-860-4179, e-mail her at MaryLou@dcccd.edu or visit www.BrookhavenCollege.edu/management. Class meets Mondays only 8:10-9:00 p.m. No textbook is required for this course.

class.title: Computer Literacy
class.description: COSC 1300-2421 is online and requires access to the Internet and e-mail along with Microsoft Office 2007 software. Students without Office 2007 may purchase a very low-cost trial version for their computers or may work in a Brookhaven College lab at no cost. The course orientation will be given online, but an optional on-campus orientation will be offered during the first week of class for students seeking extra help. For more information, call 972-860-4746 or e-mail bhcCIT@dcccd.edu or enter the Dallas TeleCollege Web site at http://dallastelecollege.dcccd.edu.

class.title: Prog Fund 2 - Intro C#

class.title: Cultural Studies
class.alt-description: Mexico: A Cultural Perspective. This theme-driven, multicultural, interdisciplinary course will study the historical, political, social, religious, artistic and business traditions of Mexico. Students must have Internet access and a current e-mail address. Students may obtain a free e-mail account by visiting www.BrookhavenCollege.edu, then clicking on "N" for NetMail.

class.title: Cultural Studies
class.description: This course focuses on topics related to Caribbean culture and arts, with special emphasis on the impact of the African influence within the broader Caribbean, Central and South American regions. Students must have Internet access and a current e-mail address. Students may obtain a free e-mail account by visiting www.BrookhavenCollege.edu, then clicking on "N" for NetMail.

class.title: Prin Econ
class.description: This is an interdisciplinary Learning Community of Economics and History. Students who register for ECON 2302-2003 must also register for HIST 1302-2007. These courses meet Tuesday and Thursday from 10:30 a.m.-1:20 p.m., offering a total of six hours of CORE curriculum credit. These courses will focus particular attention to the economic development of the country as it moves from the 19th century into the 20th century as an industrial power.
class.alt-description: This is an interdisciplinary Learning Community of Economics and History. Students who register for ECON 2302-2003 must also register for HIST 1302-2007. These courses meet Tuesday and Thursday from 10:30 a.m.-1:20 p.m., offering a total of six hours of CORE curriculum credit. These courses will focus particular attention to the economic development of the country as it moves from the 19th century into the 20th century as an industrial power. "Principles of Micro-Economics"

class.title: Composition I
class.description: This is an interdisciplinary Learning Community of English and History. Students who register for ENGL 1301-2051 must also register for HIST 1301-2051. The documents, biographies and literature of early America illustrate the narrative of history. This course makes use of eCampus technology and expects active student involvement. Emphasis is on writing and exploration of ideas rather than standardized tests.

Emphasis is on writing and exploration of ideas rather than standardized tests.

class.title: Composition I
class.description: This is an interdisciplinary Learning Community of English and History. Students who register for ENGL 1301-2052 must also register for HIST 1301-2053. class.title: Composition I
class.description: This is an interdisciplinary Learning Community of English and Government. Students who register for ENGL 1301-2053 must also register for GOVT 2301-2013. This course meets TR from 9 a.m. to 11:50 a.m, offering a total of 6 hours of Core Curriculum credit. The course theme is "Personalities, Politics and Principles." Get to know the real and fictional characters who helped shape our democracy and how we think about personal liberties and our political future.
class.alt-description: This is an interdisciplinary Learning Community of English and Government. Students who register for ENGL 1301-2053 must also register for GOVT 2301-2013. This course meets TR from 9 a.m. to 11:50 a.m, offering a total of 6 hours of CORE curriculum credit. The course theme is "Personalities, Politics and Principles." Get to know the real and fictional characters who helped shape our democracy and how we think about personal liberties and our political future. Taking these two courses together offers students several benefits including less expensive texts, unified assignments, and constant student/instructor interaction.

class.title: American Government
class.description: This is an interdisciplinary Learning Community of English and Government. Students who register for GOVT 2301-2013 must also register for ENGL 1301-2053. This course meets TR from 9 a.m. to 11:50 a.m., offering a total of 6 hours of CORE curriculum credit. Personalities, Politics and Principles. Get to know the real and fictional characters who helped shape our democracy and how to think about personal liberties and our political future.

This course meets TR from 9 a.m. to 11:50 a.m., offering a total of 6 hours of CORE curriculum credit. Personalities, Politics and Principles. class.title: American Government
class.description: This is an online "Power" course, meaning it is designed to fulfill both Government requirements in one semester. It is strongly advised (but not required) students enroll in both sections of this unique program. If you only need to take one course, you may do so. The course sections for this program are GOVT 2301-2424 and GOVT 2302-2428. The course will be conducted totally online, and there is one textbook for both courses. For more information, e-mail the instructor at aDin@dcccd.edu.

class.title: History of the U.S.
class.description: Tutorials are part of this class.

class.title: History of the U.S.
class.description: This is an interdisciplinary Learning Community of English and history. Students must also enroll in ENGL 1301-2051. This Learning Community meets MW at 9-11:50a.m. The documents, biographies and literature of early America illustrate the narrative of history. The course makes use of eCampus technology and expects active student involvement. Emphasis is on writing and exploration of ideas rather than standardized tests.

class.title: History of the U.S.
class.description: This is an interdisciplinary Learning Community of history and economics. Students who register for HIST 1302-2007 must also register for ECON 2302-2003. This Learning Community meets TR from 10:30 a.m.-1:20 p.m., offering a total of 6 hours of CORE Curriculum credit. History 1302 covers the history of the United States from Reconstruction to present day. These courses will focus particular attention to the economic development of the country as it moves from the 19th century into the 20th century industrial power.

These courses will focus particular attention to the economic development of the country as it moves from the 19th century into the 20th century industrial power.

class.title: ASP.NET Web Programming
class.description: INEW 1440-2426 covers Web programming with databases using Microsoft Visual Studio with Visual Basic or C# and Access and SQL Server databases. Students who take this course should already be familiar with basic HTML and basic programming in VB or C# (ITSC 2435, ITSE 1432, BCIS 1431, ITSE 1430 or equivalent experience). It is online and requires access to the Internet and e-mail. Orientation will be given online. For more information call 972-860-4329, e-mail bhcCITWeb@dcccd.edu or enter the Dallas TeleCollege Web site at http://dallastelecollege.dcccd.edu.

class.title: Intro to Computers/Windows XP
class.description: Introduction to Computers and Windows XP is a beginning computer course that focuses on the terminology of the Microsoft Windows XP operating system. The components of personal computers will be covered: hardware, menu bars, toolbars and shortcuts. Students will also learn to name, save, locate and print files as well as how to use the word processing program to create, edit and format files.

class.title: Music Appreciation
class.description: This four-weekend course is designed to impart an understanding of classical music as an element of contemporary culture and to develop the power of listening intelligently. Masterworks in music literature will be explored through attending live performances. No technical knowledge is required. An additional fee of $100 for Dallas Symphony Orchestra tickets must be paid by Oct. 9. For more information, contact Professor Gamblin-Bullock at 972-860-4548.
class.alt-description: This four-weekend course is designed to impart an understanding of classical music as an element of contemporary culture and to develop the power of listening intelligently. Masterworks in music literature will be explored through attending live performances. No technical knowledge is required. An additional fee of $100 for Dallas Symphony Orchestra tickets must be paid by Oct. 9. For more information, contact Professor Gamblin-Bullock at 972-860-4548.

class.title: Music Literature
class.alt-description: For more information, please call Octavio Gutierrez at 972-860-4720. Orientation is Aug. 28 at 11 a.m. in Room D207. If the institution to which the student wishes to transfer requires only one music literature course, the student should take MUSI 1308. If it requires two literature courses, the student should take MUSI 1308 and MUSI 1309. These courses are taught in English with a bilingual instructor.

class.title: Beginning Lifetime Sports Act.
class.description: This class is for ECHS students only. Beginning level skills in various lifetime sports (soccer, tennis and archery) are presented as well as rules, etiquette, safety, strategy, offensive and defensive elements, conditioning activities and physical assessments where appropriate.
class.alt-description: This class is for ECHS students only. Beginning level skills in various lifetime sports (soccer, tennis and archery) are presented as well as rules, etiquette, safety, strategy, offensive and defensive elements, conditioning activities and physical assessments where appropriate.

class.title: Beginning Lifetime Sports Act.
class.description: This combination yoga/Pilates course is designed for beginning to intermediate students. It utilizes low-impact aerobic warmups, poses and calisthenics to improve flexibility, balance and posture as well as to equalize muscle strength throughout the body. Focus will be on breathing and relaxation.
class.alt-description: This combination yoga/Pilates course is designed for beginning to intermediate students. It utilizes low-impact aerobic warmups, poses and calisthenics to improve flexibility, balance and posture as well as to equalize muscle strength throughout the body. Focus will be on breathing and relaxation.

class.title: Boot Camp Conditioning
class.description: This course will focus on improving fitness through a "boot camp" format that meets daily for a six-week period. It will include a variety of moderate-to-intense cardio, strength, flexibility, balance, agility and coordination exercises. In addition, students will gain an understanding of exercise and its effect on the body.
class.alt-description: This course will focus on improving fitness through a "boot camp" format that meets daily for a six-week period. It will include a variety of moderate-to-intense cardio, strength, flexibility, balance, agility and coordination exercises. In addition, students will gain an understanding of exercise and its effect on the body.

class.title: Beginning Lifetime Sports Act.
class.description: Class will learn the basic steps of smooth dances such as waltz, foxtrot, tango; Latin dances such as cha cha, merengue, rhumba, mambo; and East Coast swing. Individuals as well as couples are welcome.
class.alt-description: Class will learn the basic steps of smooth dances such as waltz, foxtrot and tango; Latin dances such as cha cha, merengue, rhumba and mambo; and East Coast swing. Individuals as well as couples are welcome.

class.title: Beginning Softball
class.description: Course content includes the basic playing skills of softball at the beginner level as well as rules, strategies, safety, offensive and defensive elements and competitive activities. Students must provide their own gloves. Contact Kevin Hurst at kHurst@dcccd.edu with any questions.

class.title: Cond Exercise

class.title: Beginning Self Defense
class.description: This course offers Choy Li Fut, one of the most authentic and effective styles of Shaolin Kung Fu for health and self defense. It combines the agile footwork of Northern Shaolin with the intricate hand techniques of Southern Shaolin. Uniform is required and will be discussed at first meeting. Certified by the Plum Blossom International Federation.
class.alt-description: This course offers Choy Li Fut, one of the most authentic and effective styles of Shaolin Kung Fu for health and self defense. Certified by the Plum Blossom International Federation.

class.title: Lifetime Fitness & Wellness I
class.description: This course offers a total fitness package including physical assessment with computer printout, weight training, aerobic activities and wellness concepts.

class.title: Health for Today
class.description: This class is for ECHS students only. Emphasis is placed on relating course content to lifestyle to foster a better understanding of the major health issues of today. Current issues include, but are not limited to: emotional health, chemical use and abuse, human sexuality, major diseases, physical fitness, nutrition, aging, death and dying. This course does not satisfy the physical education activity course requirement.

This course does not satisfy the physical education activity course requirement.

class.title: First Aid Safety
class.description: This class covers both theory and practice in advanced first aid and emergency care. First Aid and CPR/AED certifications may be earned.
class.alt-description: This class covers both theory and practice in advanced first aid and emergency care. First Aid and CPR/AED certifications may be earned.

class.title: Beginning Yoga
class.description: This combination yoga/Pilates course is designed for beginning to intermediate students. It utilizes low-impact aerobic warm-ups, poses and calisthenics to improve flexibility, balance and posture as well as to equalize muscle strength throughout the body. Focus will be on breathing and relaxation.

class.description: This course is an internal or soft Chinese martial art form characterized by low, non-impact movements designed to build strength and balance and to reduce stress.

class.title: Introductory General Physics
class.description: PHYS 1401 is an algebra/trigonometry-based physics course for pre-dental, pre-pharmacy and pre-architecture majors and other students who need a two-semester technical course in physics. It is recommended that students take MATH 1414 (College Algebra) and MATH 1316 (Trigonometry) prior to taking PHYS 1401.

class.title: Fundamentals of Astronomy
class.description: PHYS 1411 is a four-hour lab science course for non-science majors. Students are required to attend some Wednesday evening observation sessions. Schedule will be announced in lab.
class.alt-description: PHYS 1411 is a four-hour lab science course for non-science majors. Students are required to attend some Wednesday evening observation sessions. Schedule will be announced in lab.

class.description: Orientation for PHYS 1411-2426 online course will be Aug. 25, 6-7 p.m. in Room K251. Students must have access to a computer with Internet and e-mail. Lectures, labs and test are online. Some outdoor observations are required, which may be done on campus or alternate locations.

class.title: Physical Science
class.description: Fire model rockets and learn science "magic." This core lab science course is designed for non-science majors and requires a minimum level of math skills such as those covered in DMAT 0090.
class.alt-description: Fire model rockets and learn science "magic." This core lab science course is designed for non-science majors and requires a minimum level of math skills such as those covered in DMAT 0090.

class.title: General Physics
class.description: PHYS 2425 is a calculus-based physics course designed for physics, chemistry, mathematics and engineering majors. Credit or concurrent enrollment in MATH 2513 (Calculus I) is required.
class.alt-description: PHYS 2425 is a calculus-based physics course designed for physics, chemistry, mathematics and engineering majors. Credit or concurrent enrollment in MATH 2513 (Calculus I) is required.

class.title: General Physics
class.description: PHYS 2425 is a calculus-based physics course designed for physics, chemistry, mathematics and engineering majors. Credit or concurrent enrollment in MATH 2513 (Calculus I) is required.
class.alt-description: PHYS 2425 is a calculus-based physics course designed for physics, chemistry, mathematics and engineering majors. Credit or concurrent enrollment in MATH 2513 (Calculus I) is required.

class.title: Computer Basics
class.description: This course is required for the Medical Front Office Assistant Marketable Skills Achievement Award. The course provides a basic overview of Microsoft's operating system, such as the desktop, taskbar, menus and file management.
class.alt-description: This course is required for the Medical Front Office Assistant Marketable Skills Achievement Award. The course provides a basic overview of Microsoft's operating system, such as the desktop, taskbar, menus and file management.

class.title: Creating With Windows 7
class.description: Creating Albums, Videos and Presentations will cover how to use Microsoft and other free software to organize digital photos, create picture albums, edit home movies and publish them to the web for sharing with others. Students should bring a USB flash drive containing their pictures and videos to each session.
class.alt-description: Creating Albums, Videos and Presentations will cover how to use Microsoft and other free software to organize digital photos, create picture albums, edit home movies and publish them to the web for sharing with others. Students should bring a USB flash drive containing their pictures and videos to each session.

class.title: Buying/Selling on the Internet
class.description: Buying/Selling on the Internet will include registration procedures, safe buying practices, evaluating site security, liability and fraud, bidding on auctions and eBay. Students will learn how to write an effective ad, format ad photos and become acquainted with feedback and rating, listing tools and different payments systems. Recommended prerequisite: Intro. to Windows and Internet, Part I.
class.alt-description: Buying/Selling on the Internet will include registration procedures, safe buying practices, evaluating site security, liability and fraud, bidding on auctions and eBay. Students will learn how to write an effective ad, format ad photos and become acquainted with feedback and rating, listing tools and different payments systems. Recommended prerequisite: Intro. to Windows and Internet, Part I.

class.title: Digital Video, Part I
class.description: Digital Video, Part I, will teach students about standard definition video, such as VHS and Hi8. Capture hardware, codecs, and basic editing, such as trimming and assembly of clips with Sony Vegas Movie Studio, will be covered. Recommended prerequisite: Intro. to Computers and Windows XP.
class.alt-description: Digital Video, Part I, will teach students about standard definition video, such as VHS and Hi8. Capture hardware, codecs, and basic editing, such as trimming and assembly of clips with Sony Vegas Movie Studio, will be covered. Recommended prerequisite: Intro. to Computers and Windows XP.

class.title: Digital Video, Part II
class.description: Desktop Digital Video, Part II, will cover how to use Sony Vegas Movie Studio to edit High Definition video using a variety of different file formats and codecs. Mastering AVCHD DVD and BD Discs will also be covered.
class.alt-description: Desktop Digital Video, Part II, will cover how to use Sony Vegas Movie Studio to edit High Definition video using a variety of different file formats and codecs. Mastering AVCHD DVD and BD Discs will also be covered.

class.title: Excel 2007, Part I
class.description: Excel 2007, Part I, will introduce students to spreadsheets and arithmetic functions. This course will include creating, editing, naming, saving and printing spreadsheets as well as navigating within worksheets. Menus, shortcuts, toolbars for formatting spreadsheets and writing basic formulas will also be covered. Recommended Prerequisite: Introduction to Windows.
class.alt-description: Excel 2007, Part I, will introduce students to spreadsheets and arithmetic functions. This course will include creating, editing, naming, saving and printing spreadsheets as well as navigating within worksheets. Menus, shortcuts, toolbars for formatting spreadsheets and writing basic formulas will also be covered. Recommended Prerequisite: Introduction to Windows.

class.title: Facebook
class.description: This course will cover online social networking using Facebook. The following topics will be covered: registration procedures, safe posting practices, personalizing privacy settings, managing friends, photos, videos, links, messaging and applications.
class.alt-description: This course will cover online social networking using Facebook. The following topics will be covered: registration procedures, safe posting practices, personalizing privacy settings, managing friends, photos, videos, links, messaging and applications.

class.title: Internet, Part II
class.description: Internet, Part II, will cover advanced e-mail functions, advanced and quick searches, and shortcuts to addressing Web sites. Students will learn how to download programs (such as games and Adobe Acrobat Reader), avoid virses and manage pop-ups, spam mail and cookies. How to personalize the Internet experience and use calendars will also be explained. Recommended prerequisites: Introduction to Windows and Internet, Part I.
class.alt-description: Internet, Part II, will cover advanced e-mail functions, advanced and quick searches, and shortcuts to addressing Web sites. Students will learn how to download programs (such as games and Adobe Acrobat Reader), avoid virses and manage pop-ups, spam mail and cookies. How to personalize the Internet experience and use calendars will also be explained. Recommended prerequisites: Introduction to Windows and Internet, Part I.

class.title: Music Player Basics
class.description: Music Play Basics will use WMP11, iTunes and Winamp, and will emphasize the basic functions of playing and managing audio files running under the Microsoft Windows operating system. Students will learn to copy (rip) music CDs to the audio library and create (burn) copies of CDs for use on other audio players. Managing the audio and video library will be covered. Recommended prerequisite: Introduction to Windows.
class.alt-description: Music Play Basics will use WMP11, iTunes and Winamp, and will emphasize the basic functions of playing and managing audio files running under the Microsoft Windows operating system. Students will learn to copy (rip) music CDs to the audio library and create (burn) copies of CDs for use on other audio players. Managing the audio and video library will be covered. Recommended prerequisite: Introduction to Windows.

class.title: PC Troubleshooting/Windows 7
class.description: PC Troubleshooting for Vista/Windows 7 will address problems such as a slow-running PC or a Windows applications malfunction. This course will investigate some actions you can take: virus, spyware and malware removal; hard drive housekeeping; system restore, recovery console, driver rollback; hardware and software-based performance improvements, reinstalling Windows and backing up the data system.
class.alt-description: PC Troubleshooting for Vista/Windows 7 will address problems such as a slow-running PC or a Windows applications malfunction. This course will investigate some actions you can take: virus, spyware and malware removal; hard drive housekeeping; system restore, recovery console, driver rollback; hardware and software-based performance improvements, reinstalling Windows and backing up the data system.

class.title: Tips/Tricks-Windows 7/ Vista
class.description: Tips and Tricks for Windows 7/Vista users will deal with understanding and using the new features and capabilities of Windows 7. Students learn easy ways to search for documents, run programs, reduce Internet risks and threats, and keep their computers running at top speed. Students also get tips on making and editing digital music and video. Recommended prerequisite: Introduction to Windows.
class.alt-description: Tips and Tricks for Windows 7/Vista users will deal with understanding and using the new features and capabilities of Windows 7. Students learn easy ways to search for documents, run programs, reduce Internet risks and threats, and keep their computers running at top speed. Students also get tips on making and editing digital music and video. Recommended prerequisite: Introduction to Windows.

class.title: Users Group/Problem Solving
class.description: Users Group & Problem Solving meets on Fridays: Sept. 3, Oct. 1, Nov. 5, and Dec. 3. Each session has a theme/topic and provides demonstrations to increase student knowledge of computers, software and the Internet. In addition, students will have the opportunity to ask questions about their own computers and the software problems they are encountering.
class.alt-description: Users Group & Problem Solving meets on Fridays: Sept. 3, Oct. 1, Nov. 5, and Dec. 3. Each session has a theme/topic and provides demonstrations to increase student knowledge of computers, software and the Internet. In addition, students will have the opportunity to ask questions about their own computers and the software problems they are encountering.

class.title: Windows Brush Up
class.description: Windows Brush Up reviews basic computer skills previously learned, and teaches new ways to use a computer. It is a hands-on course that covers all recent versions of Microsoft Windows and focuses on providing help with specific topics that class members request.
class.alt-description: Windows Brush Up reviews basic computer skills previously learned, and teaches new ways to use a computer. It is a hands-on course that covers all recent versions of Microsoft Windows and focuses on providing help with specific topics that class members request.

class.title: Windows 7/ XP / Vista Users
class.description: Windows 7 for XP/Vista Users is for experienced Windows users (Windows 98, Millennium, XP and Vista) who have made the decision to upgrade to Windows 7 or have purchased a new PC which came with Windows 7. Topics covered include determining if you need to buy the complete Windows package or can buy the upgrade bundle, the new screens' layouts and the most frequently used functions, including new and modified ones. Required prerequisite: Into to Windows XP or Vista.
class.alt-description: Windows 7 for XP/Vista Users is for experienced Windows users (Windows 98, Millennium, XP and Vista) who have made the decision to upgrade to Windows 7 or have purchased a new PC which came with Windows 7. Topics covered include determining if you need to buy the complete Windows package or can buy the upgrade bundle, the new screens' layouts and the most frequently used functions, including new and modified ones. Required prerequisite: Into to Windows XP or Vista.

class.title: Windows 7 / XP/ Vista Users
class.description: Windows 7 for XP/Vista Users is for experienced Windows users (Windows 98, Millennium, XP and Vista) who have made the decision to upgrade to Windows 7 or have purchased a new PC which came with Windows 7. Topics covered include determining if you need to buy the complete Windows package or can buy the upgrade bundle, the new screens' layouts and the most frequently used functions, including new and modified ones. Required Prerequisite: Introduction to Windows XP or Vista.
class.alt-description: Windows 7 for XP/Vista Users is for experienced Windows users (Windows 98, Millennium, XP and Vista) who have made the decision to upgrade to Windows 7 or have purchased a new PC which came with Windows 7. Topics covered include determining if you need to buy the complete Windows package or can buy the upgrade bundle, the new screens' layouts and the most frequently used functions, including new and modified ones. Required Prerequisite: Introduction to Windows XP or Vista.

class.title: Word 2007, Part I
class.description: Word 2007, Part I, will emphasize the basics of Microsoft's word processing program. Topics include creating and editing Word documents; naming, saving and printing documents; menus, toolbars and shortcuts. Students will learn how to format, cut, copy and paste text; create margins and indents; and insert graphics and text from other documents and applications. Recommended Prerequisite: Introduction to Windows.
class.alt-description: Word 2007, Part I, will emphasize the basics of Microsoft's word processing program. Topics include creating and editing Word documents; naming, saving and printing documents; menus, toolbars and shortcuts. Students will learn how to format, cut, copy and paste text; create margins and indents; and insert graphics and text from other documents and applications. Recommended Prerequisite: Introduction to Windows.

class.title: Word 2007, Part II
class.description: Word 2007, Part II, will build on the concepts learned in Word 2007, Part I to work with columns, paragraph numbering, graphics, section breaks and creating envelopes and labels. Students will also learn how to merge a database of names and addresses, how to change the default settings and refine their knowledge of advanced table techniques. Prerequisite: Word 2007, Part I.
class.alt-description: Word 2007, Part II, will build on the concepts learned in Word 2007, Part I to work with columns, paragraph numbering, graphics, section breaks and creating envelopes and labels. Students will also learn how to merge a database of names and addresses, how to change the default settings and refine their knowledge of advanced table techniques. Prerequisite: Word 2007, Part I.

class.title: Tracing Family Tree, Part I
class.description: Tracing Your Family Tree I will enable students to discover their ancestral past through a classroom genealogical journey. Using hands-on computerized searches and in-class discussion, this course will intoduce the family historian to the concepts, methods, sources and resources used in successful genealogical research.
class.alt-description: Tracing Your Family Tree I will enable students to discover their ancestral past through a classroom genealogical journey. Using hands-on computerized searches and in-class discussion, this course will intoduce the family historian to the concepts, methods, sources and resources used in successful genealogical research.

class.title: Tracing Family Tree, Part II
class.description: Tracing Your Family Tree II will continue your fascinating genealogical journey of ancestral discovery. In this course the instructor will guide students deeper into the labyrinth of traditional historical and genealogical records sources, research methods, Web sites and search engines.
class.alt-description: Tracing Your Family Tree II will continue your fascinating genealogical journey of ancestral discovery. In this course the instructor will guide students deeper into the labyrinth of traditional historical and genealogical records sources, research methods, Web sites and search engines.

class.title: Google, Part I
class.description: Google for Genealogists, Part I, will cover how to find genealogical information using search engines. Students will learn how to use genealogical mailing lists using Gmail, techniques for writing queries, how to use the U.S. GenWeb project and how to save documents, maps and images. Recommended prerequisite: Introduction to Windows and Internet Part I.
class.alt-description: Google for Genealogists, Part I, will cover how to find genealogical information using search engines. Students will learn how to use genealogical mailing lists using Gmail, techniques for writing queries, how to use the U.S. GenWeb project and how to save documents, maps and images. Recommended prerequisite: Introduction to Windows and Internet Part I.

class.title: Google, Part II
class.description: Google for Genealogists, Part II, will cover how to use Gmail for genealogical mailing lists, techniques for writing genealogical queries that get results, and how to search book collections for digital images that will assist in genealogical research. Students will learn to view, navigate, extract, print and save information in online documents.
class.alt-description: Google for Genealogists, Part II, will cover how to use Gmail for genealogical mailing lists, techniques for writing genealogical queries that get results, and how to search book collections for digital images that will assist in genealogical research. Students will learn to view, navigate, extract, print and save information in online documents.

class.title: Digital Cameras
class.description: Digital Cameras will cover the various features of a digital camera. Students will learn about the process of transferring photos to the computer, how to take pictures with an eye for computer enhancement and for use in e-mails and Web pages. Storage and retrieval of digital photos will be reviewed. If you have a camera, please bring it to class.
class.alt-description: Digital Cameras will cover the various features of a digital camera. Students will learn about the process of transferring photos to the computer, how to take pictures with an eye for computer enhancement and for use in e-mails and Web pages. Storage and retrieval of digital photos will be reviewed. If you have a camera, please bring it to class.

class.title: Digital Cameras
class.description: Digital Cameras will cover the various features of a digital camera. class.alt-description: Digital Cameras will cover the various features of a digital camera. Storage and retrieval of digital photos will be reviewed. If you have a camera, please bring it to class.

class.title: Photoshop Elements, Part I
class.description: Photoshop Elements, Part I, will help you import, organize and enhance your photos. Students also will develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening and red eye removal. Photoshop Elements 8 will be used. Recommended prerequisite: Intro. to Windows and Internet, Part I.
class.alt-description: Photoshop Elements, Part I, will help you import, organize and enhance your photos. Students also will develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening and red eye removal. Photoshop Elements 8 will be used. Recommended prerequisite: Intro. to Windows and Internet, Part I.

class.title: Photoshop Elements, Part I
class.description: Photoshop Elements, Part I, will help you import, organize and enhance your photos. Students also will develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening and red eye removal. Photoshop Element 8 will be used. Recommended Prerequisite: Introduction to Windows and Internet, Part I.
class.alt-description: Photoshop Elements, Part I, will help you import, organize and enhance your photos. Students also will develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening and red eye removal. Photoshop Element 8 will be used. Recommended Prerequisite: Introduction to Windows and Internet, Part I.

class.title: Photoshop Elements, Part II
class.description: Photoshop Elements, Part II, will build on skills from Elements Part I and cover how to correct color and exposure as well as work on dust and spot removal. Students also will use the clone tool to repair damage and remove unwanted parts of the photo. Photoshop Elements 8 will be used. Recommended Prerequisite: Photoshop Elements, Part I.
class.alt-description: Photoshop Elements, Part II, will build on skills from Elements Part I and cover how to correct color and exposure as well as work on dust and spot removal. Students also will use the clone tool to repair damage and remove unwanted parts of the photo. Photoshop Elements 8 will be used. Recommended Prerequisite: Photoshop Elements, Part I.

class.title: Photoshop Elements, Part III
class.description: Photoshop Elements, Part III, will build on skills from Elements, Part II. Students will work on a project as well as learn different ways of creating masks to isolate specific areas of photos and work with various types of layers, including text layers. You also will experiment with blend modes and plug-in filters. Photoshop Elements 8 will be used. Recommended Prerequisite: Photoshop Elements, Part II.
class.alt-description: Photoshop Elements, Part III, will build on skills from Elements, Part II. Students will work on a project as well as learn different ways of creating masks to isolate specific areas of photos and work with various types of layers, including text layers. You also will experiment with blend modes and plug-in filters. Photoshop Elements 8 will be used. Recommended Prerequisite: Photoshop Elements, Part II.

class.title: Blurb Booksmart
class.description: Blurb Booksmart will use free software from an online book publisher to help students create their own publication. Gather old family photos, memorabilia and old books in need of re-creation, or bring your own creative writing or poems for a class project. Students will be able to scan pictures and text, and learn to use templates and page layouts. Check out the bookmaking software at www.blurb.com.
class.alt-description: Blurb Booksmart will use free software from an online book publisher to help students create their own publication. Gather old family photos, memorabilia and old books in need of re-creation, or bring your own creative writing or poems for a class project. Students will be able to scan pictures and text, and learn to use templates and page layouts. Check out the bookmaking software at www.blurb.com.

class.title: iPhone, iTouch, iTunes
class.description: Get to know your mobile device and how to find and install helpful applications for everyday life. Learn how to customize, protect and set up multiple e-mail accounts on your device, as well as new features like Voice Control, Compass and video recording. Music and various other aspects of iTunes will also be covered.
class.alt-description: Get to know your mobile device and how to find and install helpful applications for everyday life. Learn how to customize, protect and set up multiple e-mail accounts on your device, as well as new features like Voice Control, Compass and video recording. Music and various other aspects of iTunes will also be covered.

class.title: Internet, Part I
class.description: Internet, Part I, will use Microsoft Internet Explorer with reference to AT&T, AOL and other services. This course will emphasize all basic e-mail functions, including attachments, searches using Google and other search engines, Web pages, Instant Messenger and discussion groups. Students will learn how to shop and purchase items online and how to perform other activities at popular Web sites. Recommended Prerequisite: Introduction to Windows.
class.alt-description: Internet, Part I, will use Microsoft Internet Explorer with reference to AT&T, AOL and other services. This course will emphasize all basic e-mail functions, including attachments, searches using Google and other search engines, Web pages, Instant Messenger and discussion groups. Students will learn how to shop and purchase items online and how to perform other activities at popular Web sites. Recommended Prerequisite: Introduction to Windows.

class.title: Internet, Part II
class.description: Internet, Part II, will cover advanced e-mail functions, advanced and quick searches, and shortcuts to addressing Web sites. Students will learn how to download programs (such as games and Adobe Acrobat Reader), avoid virses and manage pop-ups, spam mail and cookies. How to personalize the Internet experience and use of calendars will also be explained. Recommended Prerequisites: Introduction to Windows and Internet, Part I.
class.alt-description: Internet, Part II, will cover advanced e-mail functions, advanced and quick searches, and shortcuts to addressing Web sites. Students will learn how to download programs (such as games and Adobe Acrobat Reader), avoid virses and manage pop-ups, spam mail and cookies. How to personalize the Internet experience and use of calendars will also be explained. Recommended Prerequisites: Introduction to Windows and Internet, Part I.

class.title: Web Page Design, Part I
class.description: Web Page Design, Part I, will focus on designing a simple personal or business Web site and covers how to put photos online and create e-mail links. Students will learn about free or inexpensive Web site hosting for their personal sites. No prior knowledge of Web design is required. Students must be able to attend all classes. Recommended prerequisite: Introduction to Windows & Internet, Part I.
class.alt-description: Web Page Design, Part I, will focus on designing a simple personal or business Web site and covers how to put photos online and create e-mail links. Students will learn about free or inexpensive Web site hosting for their personal sites. No prior knowledge of Web design is required. Students must be able to attend all classes. Recommended prerequisite: Introduction to Windows & Internet, Part I.

class.title: Web Page Design, Part II
class.description: Web Page Design, Part II, will build upon the skills of Web Page Design, Part I by adding to your Web site. Students will review how to design a Web site, format lists and tables, add new pages and links, and music interactivity. Students must be able to attend all classes. Prerequisite: Web Page Design, Part I.
class.alt-description: Web Page Design, Part II, will build upon the skills of Web Page Design, Part I by adding to your Web site. Students will review how to design a Web site, format lists and tables, add new pages and links, and music interactivity. Students must be able to attend all classes. Prerequisite: Web Page Design, Part I.

course.title: St Med Ad Ex Asst Med Secret
course.long-title: Special Topics in Medical Administrative /Executive Assistant and Medical Secretary

class.title: Office Simulation
class.description: This course is required for the Medical Front Office Assistant Marketable Skills Achievement Award. The course introduces students to creating, editing, and formatting medical documents supporting the front office of a medical practice, clinic, or hospital. You must be enrolled in the Medical Front Office progam to enroll in this course.
class.alt-description: This course is required for the Medical Front Office Assistant Marketable Skills Achievement Award. The course introduces students to creating, editing, and formatting medical documents supporting the front office of a medical practice, clinic, or hospital. You must be enrolled in the Medical Front Office progam to enroll in this course.

class.title: Office Simulation

course.title: Coop Ed: Med Admin Exec Asst
course.long-title: Cooperative Education-Medical Administrative/Executive Assistant and Medical Secretary

class.title: Coop Ed: Med Admin Exec Asst
class.description: Prerequisite required: Completion of Medical Front Office Assistant Marketable Skills Achievement Award and completion or enrollment in POFT 1301, POFM 1370, POFM 1300 and POFM 1327. Students MUST be available to work a total of 160 hours in a medical clinic or hospital administrative office environment. Students must be able to meet the following classes Saturdays: Aug. 28, Sept. 25, Oct. 30 and Dec. 4. This course is a hybrid course, which combines both on-campus activities and online activities.

Students MUST be available to work a total of 160 hours in a medical clinic or hospital administrative office environment. Students must be able to meet the following classes Saturdays: Aug. 28, Sept. 25, Oct. 30 and Dec.4. This course is a hybrid course, which combines both on-campus activities and online activities.

class.title: Medical Coding Basics
class.description: Prerequisite required: MDCA 1313 Medical Terminology or an equivalent medical terminology course and completion of credits earned in Marketable Skills Achievement Award. This course is required for the Medical Front Office Assistant Level 1 Certificate and is a hybrid course, which combines both on-campus activities and online activities. For more information, call Sharon Burton at 972-860-4163.
class.alt-description: Prerequisite required: MDCA 1313 Medical Terminology or an equivalent medical terminology course and completion of credits earned in Marketable Skills Achievement Award. This course is required for the Medical Front Office Assistant Level 1 Certificate and is a hybrid course, which combines both on-campus activities and online activities. For more information, call Sharon Burton at 972-860-4163.

class.title: Medical Application Software
class.description: This course is required for the Medical Front Office Assistant Marketable Skills Achievement Award. Medisoft, a practice management software, is used to teach billing and scheduling procedures. NOTE: POFM 1302 is hybrid course, which combines both on-campus activities and online activities.
class.alt-description: This course is required for the Medical Front Office Assistant Marketable Skills Achievement Award. Medisoft, a practice management software, is used to teach billing and scheduling procedures. NOTE: POFM 1302 is hybrid course, which combines both on-campus activities and online activities.

class.title: Medical Office Procedures
class.description: This course is required for the Medical Front Office Assistant Marketable Skills Achievement Award. The course introduces medical front office careers and medical ethics and medical law as they apply to the front office setting. Specific administrative responsibilities are introduced including scheduling, records management and medical communications. NOTE: POFM 1309 is hybrid course, which combines both on-campus activities and online activities.

The course introduces medical front office careers and medical ethics and medical law as they apply to the front office setting. Specific administrative responsibilities are introduced including scheduling, records management and medical communications. NOTE: POFM 1309 is hybrid course, which combines both on-campus activities and online activities.

class.title: Medical Insurance

class.title: Medical Records Management
class.description: Prerequisite required: Completion of Medical Front Office Assistant Marketable Skills Achievement Award. The course intoduces the student to the basics of medical records management and provides opportunities to put administrative skill learned in previous courses into practice in a simulated medical setting using electronic health care records (EHR).

course.title: Spc Tpcs in Spanish Lang/Liter
course.long-title: Special Topics in Spanish Language and Literature

class.title: Beginning Spanish
class.description: Beginning Spanish will enable you to build beginning vocabulary, basic grammar and pronunciation skills. Comprehension will increase as you participate in listening and speaking exercises with classmates and the instructor. Instructional materials will be used as a way to increase skills. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class.
class.alt-description: Beginning Spanish will enable you to build beginning vocabulary, basic grammar and pronunciation skills. Comprehension will increase as you participate in listening and speaking exercises with classmates and the instructor. Instructional materials will be used as a way to increase skills. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class.

class.title: Special Topics in Spanish
class.description: Special Topics will include a grammar and vocabulary review, a survey of literature, current topics, cultural videos and discussion. New topics will be introduced each semester. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class. Recommended prerequisite: Intermediate Spanish or permission of instructor.
class.alt-description: Special Topics will include a grammar and vocabulary review, a survey of literature, current topics, cultural videos and discussion. New topics will be introduced each semester. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class. Recommended prerequisite: Intermediate Spanish or permission of instructor.
